content: "http://www.time.com/time/printout/0,8816,1880451,00.html" quote: The U.S. Catholic Church's crusade against the Freedom of Choice Act (FOCA) has all the hallmarks of a well-oiled lobbying campaign. A national postcard campaign is flooding the White House and congressional offices with messages opposing FOCA, and Catholic bishops have made defeating the abortion rights legislation a top priority. In the most recent effort to stop the bill, Cardinal Justin Rigali of Philadelphia sent a letter to every member of Congress imploring them to "please oppose FOCA." There is only one hitch. Congress isn't about to pass the Freedom of Choice Act — because no such bill has been introduced in the current Congress. At a time when the United States is gripped by economic uncertainty and faces serious challenges in hot spots around the globe, some American Catholics are finding it both curious and troubling that their church has launched a major campaign against a piece of legislation that doesn't exist and wouldn't have much chance of becoming law even if it did. To many critics, it feels like the legislative equivalent of the dog that didn't bark. The campaign against FOCA, which would essentially codify the Roe v. Wade decision by saying the government can't place limits on abortions performed before viability, began shortly after Barack Obama's election in November, at the annual general meeting of the U.S. Conference of Catholic Bishops (USCCB). In a unanimous decision, the bishops voted to "mobilize the resources of the USCCB, dioceses and the entire Catholic community" to oppose the act. A chain e-mail of unknown origin soon began making its way into Catholic inboxes, warning of an imminent threat to the anti-abortion cause. "For those of you who do not know," it read, "the Freedom of Choice Act (FOCA) is set to be signed if Congress passes it on January 21-22 of 2009. The FOCA is the next sick chapter in the book of abortion." The e-mail urged Catholics to say a novena — a devotion of dedicated prayer for nine successive days — beginning on Jan. 11 and ending the day prior to Inauguration Day. When Jan. 22 came and went without a Freedom of Choice Act becoming law, the USCCB's Committee on Pro-Life Activities announced a nationwide postcard campaign to blanket congressional offices and the White House with appeals to stop FOCA. Anti-FOCA groups on Facebook soon had more than 150,000 members and added thousands more each day. Priests started preaching against the legislation, and churches began circulating petitions to oppose its passage. In the midst of all this activity, the fact that there was no Freedom of Choice Act before the 111th Congress went largely unnoticed and unmentioned... James Salt, director of organizing for the progressive organization Catholics United, thinks the USCCB has been prodded into focusing on FOCA by misinformation from conservative groups. "These right-wing organizations are deliberatively misleading people in order to stoke the culture war," says Salt. "They're using this as a fundraising tool, as a way to gin up their relevancy. And unfortunately, some of these groups have the ear of certain bishops."... While the USCCB's literature about FOCA has been generally accurate, the chain e-mail has disseminated a number of false claims, including warnings that the proposal would force Catholic hospitals to shut down and lead to at least 100,000 more abortions each year. Some versions of the e-mail even claimed that FOCA could "result in a future amendment that would force women by law to have abortions in certain situations — and even regulate how many children women are allowed to have." In response, Catholic News Service — the official news agency affiliated with the USCCB — ran an article that began, "Internet rumors to the contrary, no Catholic hospital in the United States is in danger of closing because of the Freedom of Choice Act." Sister Carol Keehan, president and CEO of the Catholic Health Association, told the news agency that the legislation "has never contained anything that would force Catholic hospitals or Catholic personnel to do abortions or to participate in them." How like the frequent claims that "The Obama Adminstration wants to re-institute the Fairness Doctrine" (also not based on any real facts). How many of you Pro-Life readers have been taken in by these lies and have contacted your Senators and representatives to oppose a proposed law or law that doesn't even exist? Do you feel just a little bit foolish?

content: I read this a few days ago. Seriously, if you have to FABRICATE something in order to have a "cause," you need to find something new to twist your panties. They have to play make-believe, lie about it to everyone, pretend there's some sort of Red-China agenda underway to limit people's reproductive freedom, and then scream bloody murder... just so they can feel important. Wait, I mean... "self-important." They'd do a lot more in the long run to help their cause if they didn't lie to make things seem more dramatic. I wonder how many Catholics are going to feel completely disillusioned or deceived when they realize that the church lied to them to get them to donate more money and so on. I can respect both sides of this issue - because I've been on both sides at different times, and I still sympathize with both - but I can't stomach lying to promote a cause.

content: quote: During his tenure in the United States Senate, Barack Obama co-sponsored the 2007 Senate version of the Freedom of Choice Act (S. 1173). Responding to a question regarding how he would preserve reproductive rights in a speech given to the Planned Parenthood Action Fund on July 17, 2007, Obama declared, "The first thing I'd do, as president, is sign the Freedom of Choice Act. That's the first thing that I'd do." What Catholics must do is hope that this was just another false political promise made by the Obama!

content: The one who should feel foolish, if not downright stupid, is the OP. While the bill has not been formally introduced in this Congress, it was in the last Congress (as well as in 1989 and 1993) ... and was co-sponsored by POTUS 44. Since NARAL has been and is trumpeting this legislation and since it seems likely that it will be reintroduced in the current Congress, it seems perfectly reasonable to me to oppose that which NARAL is lobbying for extensively. If NARAL and their ilk back away from their support for the bill, perhaps the Catholic Church will not see the need for a vocal opposition. Silly and superficial thread ... fabricated and slanted issue ... even if (or perhaps because) it originated with Time. That the bill has not been introduced yet in this Congress does not make it mythical ... it is very real.

content: quote: Still, it's not on the table at the moment. It hasn't been presented to this congress. Your dismissal of the FOCA brings to mind Martin Niemoller. He was a German pastor who supported Adolf Hitler because they were both anti-communists. Then Hitler took another step and not only wanted total separation of Church and State but that the State was supreme and Niemoller protested. Niemoller organized other clergymen to protest the laws proposed by Nazis and their 'blame' of various groups for the economic and social woes of Germany. Others gave in to the Nazis' threats. Hitler arrested Niemoller and confined him in the Sachsenhausen and Dachau concentration camps. Niemoller was released in 1945 by the Allies. His poem is well-known, frequently quoted, and is a popular model for describing the dangers of political apathy, as it often begins with specific and targeted fear and hatred which soon escalates out of control. "When the Nazis came for the communists, I remained silent; I was not a communist. When they locked up the social democrats, I remained silent; I was not a social democrat. When they came for the trade unionists, I did not speak out; I was not a trade unionist. When they came for the Jews, I remained silent; I was not a Jew. When they came for me, there was no one left to speak out." Hitler claimed to be a Christian and was also a great orator making promises to each group of Germans on how he would make life better and 'fairer'! Our 'Great Depression' was mild compared to what was taking place in Germany and throughout Europe at the same time. He first eroded then destroyed German rights similar to those we call our "Bill of Rights" - Freedom of Speech; Freedom of Religion; Right to bear arms; unwarranted Search and Seizure; etc. Contrary to popular belief, slavery was a minor factor of the causes of our Civil War. Economically, both the Industrialized North and more rural South relied on 'cheap' labor. The North because of its manufacturing and urban centers could rely on the population to provide that work force. Wages were so low, households were barely able to survive but the 'American Dream' of advancement was there and as most were from the European 'serfdom' heritage; it was better than what they were used to. The Rural south also needed a nearby work force for the larger 'plantations' and cheap labor - Slavery. The second major factor was the difference between State rights and Federal control. Again do to diparity of the population in size and economic status, the Southern States were largly ignored in receiving benefit of a Federal Government or even much voice in its operation. Similar to today with the smaller States getting a few crumbs and having little influence over the Federal System or their own resources. Lincoln inherited the 'Civil War' from James Buchanan; Seven States had already seceded and Lincoln was not even on the ballot in the 'Slave States'. Hopfully our clearer heads will prevail today but only if we listen, watch and protest! ... and this means that we have to make our voices heard before our Government Officials propose or enact legislation or policy not after the fact.

content: Okay Zippo, that was a lovely history lesson (of information I already knew), but it has nothing to do with the fact that the Catholic Church is still pretending that this bill is currently being considered by the Congress. Additionally, the FoCA was a bill intended to increase individual rights, not decrease them. You're comparing the implications of this bill to the restrictions on human rights perpetrated by the Nazi regime. A disgusting comparison, at best. You also seem to be comparing Hitler to Obama. Please correct me if I'm wrong, but if you are... as an American of Jewish ancestry, I say that you've just stepped WAY over the line. Besides, in terms of restricting rights, were you this vocal about defending your freedoms that were trampled by the Patriot Act? People protested the Patriot Act, and the right-wing called them unpatriotic traitors and terrorist supporters. Hitler was the classic extreme of right-wing politics. Perhaps we should take note of this.

content: If I wanted to compare Hitler to Obama, I would say it! I've never been one to be politically correct and if that offends, so be it - As to "increasing individual rights" which individual; the group that finds the 'right' immoral or unethical? As a 'God believing' thinking creature, my obligation is to stand firm on my moral foundation even if I have to stand alone! I associate on occassion with society but I live with 'myself" and I want to view that person I see in the mirror as one I can be proud of, not some wimp that follows the crowd or easy way. I am an American of Celtic ancestry, not by choice, but I did choose to follow the philosophy of a Jew! I have also relied on that Jew to lead me to salvation! quote: Besides, in terms of restricting rights, were you this vocal about defending your freedoms that were trampled by the Patriot Act? As a political or moral issue? ... or gun control; or ... My priorities are my God, my Family, and my Country - in that order. The patriot act did not 'erase' my rights or those of any other American citizen but it did limit those rights. It was a political choice of 'Safety' over 'freedom' due to a threat to both. Although, I have never read the complete Patriot act, from what I have gleaned, it was mor an inconvenience than a 'trampling' of mine and others rights or freedoms. quote: Hitler was the classic extreme of right-wing politics. Perhaps we should take note of this. Hitler right wing? Stalin left wing? I don't think you can pigeonhole anyone, although both were fanatical in their beliefs and practices. Glad to know that my History Lesson was information you already knew. But as with all 'lessons', the importance is what you do with that knowlege; in other words, How do you apply the lesson? As Maya Angelou said, "History, despite its wrenching pain, cannot be unlived, but if faced with courage, need not be lived again."

content: quote: Originally posted by 54D_Zippo: Although, I have never read the complete Patriot act, from what I have gleaned, it was mor an inconvenience than a 'trampling' of mine and others rights or freedoms. Then I would highly suggest that you DO read it, and try to internalize the extent of the risk to our REAL Constitutional Rights and Civil Liberties it actually posed, and the times when it actually DID impose on the Constitutional Rights of American citizens who were not in any way affiliated with terrorists. We had members of the press being arrested, harassed, and blocked, all under the carte blanche of the Patriot Act. These stories were conveniently ignored (read: hushed up) in the mainstream media. As for people's religious freedom - it is a wonderful thing that all people in the United States are supposed to have religious freedom. However, that right is also meant to ensure that the religious beliefs of one group are not imposed on another group. Example: You believe that it is evil to wear the color orange. You have the right to not wear orange. You can not stop someone else from wearing orange. You claim youy religion prohibits abortion. Having read the Bible more than once, I've not seen any passage that equates abortion with murder, but hey, believe whatever you want. You have the right to never participate in an abortion if you believe it's evil. However, imposing your religious beliefs on someone else restricts their freedoms, and the "fine line" between infanticide and abortion of a non-viable fetus isn't really such a fine line from a medical stance. But I can agree with one thing you said: You can't pigeonhole extremism. I think we can recognize real extremism when we see it, and can pretty much agree it's bad news.

That's typically late 2nd trimester or early 3rd trimester, when the fetus starts to develop the neurological functions of a baby. content: quote: Originally posted by transport1: Like the other's he's already signed into law, the ones that we still don't know about. Bout as transparent as aluminum. Oppsy Transport1, seems your behind the times once again Oppsy Transport1, seems your behind the times once again... quote: Air Force testing new transparent armor -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Story Tools Printable story E-mail story Subscribe now -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- by Laura Lundin Air Force Research Laboratory Public Affairs 10/17/2005 - WRIGHT-PATTERSON AIR FORCE BASE, Ohio (AFPN) -- Engineers here are testing a new kind of transparent armor -- stronger and lighter than traditional materials -- that could stop armor-piercing weapons from penetrating vehicle windows. The Air Force Research Laboratory's materials and manufacturing directorate is testing aluminum oxynitride -- ALONtm -- as a replacement for the traditional multi-layered glass transparencies now used in existing ground and air armored vehicles. The test is being done in conjunction with the Army Research Laboratory at Aberdeen Proving Grounds, Md., and University of Dayton Research Institute, Ohio. ALONtm is a ceramic compound with a high compressive strength and durability. When polished, it is the premier transparent armor for use in armored vehicles, said. 1st Lt. Joseph La Monica, transparent armor sub-direction lead "The substance itself is light years ahead of glass," he said, adding that it offers "higher performance and lighter weight." Traditional transparent armor is thick layers of bonded glass. The new armor combines the transparent ALONtm piece as a strike plate, a middle section of glass and a polymer backing. Each layer is visibly thinner than the traditional layers. ALONtm is virtually scratch resistant, offers substantial impact resistance, and provides better durability and protection against armor piercing threats, at roughly half the weight and half the thickness of traditional glass transparent armor, said the lieutenant. but keep trying.

title: The Catholic Crusade Against a Mythical Abortion Bill

content: "http://www.time.com/time/printout/0,8816,1880451,00.html" quote: The U.S. Catholic Church's crusade against the Freedom of Choice Act (FOCA) has all the hallmarks of a well-oiled lobbying campaign. A national postcard campaign is flooding the White House and congressional offices with messages opposing FOCA, and Catholic bishops have made defeating the abortion rights legislation a top priority. In the most recent effort to stop the bill, Cardinal Justin Rigali of Philadelphia sent a letter to every member of Congress imploring them to "please oppose FOCA." There is only one hitch. Congress isn't about to pass the Freedom of Choice Act — because no such bill has been introduced in the current Congress. At a time when the United States is gripped by economic uncertainty and faces serious challenges in hot spots around the globe, some American Catholics are finding it both curious and troubling that their church has launched a major campaign against a piece of legislation that doesn't exist and wouldn't have much chance of becoming law even if it did. To many critics, it feels like the legislative equivalent of the dog that didn't bark. The campaign against FOCA, which would essentially codify the Roe v. Wade decision by saying the government can't place limits on abortions performed before viability, began shortly after Barack Obama's election in November, at the annual general meeting of the U.S. Conference of Catholic Bishops (USCCB). In a unanimous decision, the bishops voted to "mobilize the resources of the USCCB, dioceses and the entire Catholic community" to oppose the act. A chain e-mail of unknown origin soon began making its way into Catholic inboxes, warning of an imminent threat to the anti-abortion cause. "For those of you who do not know," it read, "the Freedom of Choice Act (FOCA) is set to be signed if Congress passes it on January 21-22 of 2009. The FOCA is the next sick chapter in the book of abortion." The e-mail urged Catholics to say a novena — a devotion of dedicated prayer for nine successive days — beginning on Jan. 11 and ending the day prior to Inauguration Day. When Jan. 22 came and went without a Freedom of Choice Act becoming law, the USCCB's Committee on Pro-Life Activities announced a nationwide postcard campaign to blanket congressional offices and the White House with appeals to stop FOCA. Anti-FOCA groups on Facebook soon had more than 150,000 members and added thousands more each day. Priests started preaching against the legislation, and churches began circulating petitions to oppose its passage. In the midst of all this activity, the fact that there was no Freedom of Choice Act before the 111th Congress went largely unnoticed and unmentioned... James Salt, director of organizing for the progressive organization Catholics United, thinks the USCCB has been prodded into focusing on FOCA by misinformation from conservative groups. "These right-wing organizations are deliberatively misleading people in order to stoke the culture war," says Salt. "They're using this as a fundraising tool, as a way to gin up their relevancy. And unfortunately, some of these groups have the ear of certain bishops."... While the USCCB's literature about FOCA has been generally accurate, the chain e-mail has disseminated a number of false claims, including warnings that the proposal would force Catholic hospitals to shut down and lead to at least 100,000 more abortions each year. Some versions of the e-mail even claimed that FOCA could "result in a future amendment that would force women by law to have abortions in certain situations — and even regulate how many children women are allowed to have." In response, Catholic News Service — the official news agency affiliated with the USCCB — ran an article that began, "Internet rumors to the contrary, no Catholic hospital in the United States is in danger of closing because of the Freedom of Choice Act." Sister Carol Keehan, president and CEO of the Catholic Health Association, told the news agency that the legislation "has never contained anything that would force Catholic hospitals or Catholic personnel to do abortions or to participate in them." How like the frequent claims that "The Obama Adminstration wants to re-institute the Fairness Doctrine" (also not based on any real facts). How many of you Pro-Life readers have been taken in by these lies and have contacted your Senators and representatives to oppose a proposed law or law that doesn't even exist? Do you feel just a little bit foolish?

content: I read this a few days ago. Seriously, if you have to FABRICATE something in order to have a "cause," you need to find something new to twist your panties. They have to play make-believe, lie about it to everyone, pretend there's some sort of Red-China agenda underway to limit people's reproductive freedom, and then scream bloody murder... just so they can feel important. Wait, I mean... "self-important." They'd do a lot more in the long run to help their cause if they didn't lie to make things seem more dramatic. I wonder how many Catholics are going to feel completely disillusioned or deceived when they realize that the church lied to them to get them to donate more money and so on. I can respect both sides of this issue - because I've been on both sides at different times, and I still sympathize with both - but I can't stomach lying to promote a cause.

Responding to a question regarding how he would preserve reproductive rights in a speech given to the Planned Parenthood Action Fund on July 17, 2007, Obama declared, "The first thing I'd do, as president, is sign the Freedom of Choice Act. That's the first thing that I'd do." What Catholics must do is hope that this was just another false political promise made by the Obama!

content: The one who should feel foolish, if not downright stupid, is the OP. While the bill has not been formally introduced in this Congress, it was in the last Congress (as well as in 1989 and 1993) ... and was co-sponsored by POTUS 44. Since NARAL has been and is trumpeting this legislation and since it seems likely that it will be reintroduced in the current Congress, it seems perfectly reasonable to me to oppose that which NARAL is lobbying for extensively. If NARAL and their ilk back away from their support for the bill, perhaps the Catholic Church will not see the need for a vocal opposition. Silly and superficial thread ... fabricated and slanted issue ... even if (or perhaps because) it originated with Time. That the bill has not been introduced yet in this Congress does not make it mythical ... it is very real.

content: quote: Still, it's not on the table at the moment. It hasn't been presented to this congress. Your dismissal of the FOCA brings to mind Martin Niemoller. He was a German pastor who supported Adolf Hitler because they were both anti-communists. Then Hitler took another step and not only wanted total separation of Church and State but that the State was supreme and Niemoller protested. Niemoller organized other clergymen to protest the laws proposed by Nazis and their 'blame' of various groups for the economic and social woes of Germany. Others gave in to the Nazis' threats. Hitler arrested Niemoller and confined him in the Sachsenhausen and Dachau concentration camps. Niemoller was released in 1945 by the Allies. His poem is well-known, frequently quoted, and is a popular model for describing the dangers of political apathy, as it often begins with specific and targeted fear and hatred which soon escalates out of control. "When the Nazis came for the communists, I remained silent; I was not a communist. When they locked up the social democrats, I remained silent; I was not a social democrat. When they came for the trade unionists, I did not speak out; I was not a trade unionist. When they came for the Jews, I remained silent; I was not a Jew. When they came for me, there was no one left to speak out." Hitler claimed to be a Christian and was also a great orator making promises to each group of Germans on how he would make life better and 'fairer'! Our 'Great Depression' was mild compared to what was taking place in Germany and throughout Europe at the same time. He first eroded then destroyed German rights similar to those we call our "Bill of Rights" - Freedom of Speech; Freedom of Religion; Right to bear arms; unwarranted Search and Seizure; etc. Contrary to popular belief, slavery was a minor factor of the causes of our Civil War. Economically, both the Industrialized North and more rural South relied on 'cheap' labor. The North because of its manufacturing and urban centers could rely on the population to provide that work force. Wages were so low, households were barely able to survive but the 'American Dream' of advancement was there and as most were from the European 'serfdom' heritage; it was better than what they were used to. The Rural south also needed a nearby work force for the larger 'plantations' and cheap labor - Slavery. The second major factor was the difference between State rights and Federal control. Again do to diparity of the population in size and economic status, the Southern States were largly ignored in receiving benefit of a Federal Government or even much voice in its operation. Similar to today with the smaller States getting a few crumbs and having little influence over the Federal System or their own resources. Lincoln inherited the 'Civil War' from James Buchanan; Seven States had already seceded and Lincoln was not even on the ballot in the 'Slave States'. Hopfully our clearer heads will prevail today but only if we listen, watch and protest! ... and this means that we have to make our voices heard before our Government Officials propose or enact legislation or policy not after the fact.

I associate on occassion with society but I live with 'myself" and I want to view that person I see in the mirror as one I can be proud of, not some wimp that follows the crowd or easy way. I am an American of Celtic ancestry, not by choice, but I did choose to follow the philosophy of a Jew! That's typically late 2nd trimester or early 3rd trimester, when the fetus starts to develop the neurological functions of a baby. That would mean that Biblical Times (usually considered from the time of Abraham) ignored the knowledge of the Greeks, Egyptian, Persians, and Babylonians concerning birth: they based pregnancy on a number of factors such as 'periods', nipple color & development, and urine; and these changes were early in the first trimester. There was also a universal protection of pregnant women by all 'ancient cultures' which I would assume meant that the ancients knew that "Life" resided in the womb. Ancient languages used the same term for the unborn and the child out of the womb. Modern 'scientists' and abortion supporters are the ones that call the life a fetus; to the rest of us, its a baby! Similar to the Soldiers calling an enemy: Nips, Krauts, ****s, Ragheads, etc. - if we can dehumanize them, it's easier to kill them.

content: quote: Originally posted by transport1: Like the other's he's already signed into law, the ones that we still don't know about. Bout as transparent as aluminum. Oppsy Transport1, seems your behind the times once again Oppsy Transport1, seems your behind the times once again... quote: Air Force testing new transparent armor -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Story Tools Printable story E-mail story Subscribe now -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- by Laura Lundin Air Force Research Laboratory Public Affairs 10/17/2005 - WRIGHT-PATTERSON AIR FORCE BASE, Ohio (AFPN) -- Engineers here are testing a new kind of transparent armor -- stronger and lighter than traditional materials -- that could stop armor-piercing weapons from penetrating vehicle windows. The Air Force Research Laboratory's materials and manufacturing directorate is testing aluminum oxynitride -- ALONtm -- as a replacement for the traditional multi-layered glass transparencies now used in existing ground and air armored vehicles. The test is being done in conjunction with the Army Research Laboratory at Aberdeen Proving Grounds, Md., and University of Dayton Research Institute, Ohio. ALONtm is a ceramic compound with a high compressive strength and durability. When polished, it is the premier transparent armor for use in armored vehicles, said. 1st Lt. Joseph La Monica, transparent armor sub-direction lead "The substance itself is light years ahead of glass," he said, adding that it offers "higher performance and lighter weight." Traditional transparent armor is thick layers of bonded glass. The new armor combines the transparent ALONtm piece as a strike plate, a middle section of glass and a polymer backing. Each layer is visibly thinner than the traditional layers. ALONtm is virtually scratch resistant, offers substantial impact resistance, and provides better durability and protection against armor piercing threats, at roughly half the weight and half the thickness of traditional glass transparent armor, said the lieutenant. but keep trying.

title: The Catholic Crusade Against a Mythical Abortion Bill

content: "http://www.time.com/time/printout/0,8816,1880451,00.html" quote: The U.S. Catholic Church's crusade against the Freedom of Choice Act (FOCA) has all the hallmarks of a well-oiled lobbying campaign. A national postcard campaign is flooding the White House and congressional offices with messages opposing FOCA, and Catholic bishops have made defeating the abortion rights legislation a top priority. In the most recent effort to stop the bill, Cardinal Justin Rigali of Philadelphia sent a letter to every member of Congress imploring them to "please oppose FOCA." There is only one hitch. Congress isn't about to pass the Freedom of Choice Act — because no such bill has been introduced in the current Congress. At a time when the United States is gripped by economic uncertainty and faces serious challenges in hot spots around the globe, some American Catholics are finding it both curious and troubling that their church has launched a major campaign against a piece of legislation that doesn't exist and wouldn't have much chance of becoming law even if it did. To many critics, it feels like the legislative equivalent of the dog that didn't bark. The campaign against FOCA, which would essentially codify the Roe v. Wade decision by saying the government can't place limits on abortions performed before viability, began shortly after Barack Obama's election in November, at the annual general meeting of the U.S. Conference of Catholic Bishops (USCCB). In a unanimous decision, the bishops voted to "mobilize the resources of the USCCB, dioceses and the entire Catholic community" to oppose the act. A chain e-mail of unknown origin soon began making its way into Catholic inboxes, warning of an imminent threat to the anti-abortion cause. "For those of you who do not know," it read, "the Freedom of Choice Act (FOCA) is set to be signed if Congress passes it on January 21-22 of 2009. The FOCA is the next sick chapter in the book of abortion." The e-mail urged Catholics to say a novena — a devotion of dedicated prayer for nine successive days — beginning on Jan. 11 and ending the day prior to Inauguration Day. When Jan. 22 came and went without a Freedom of Choice Act becoming law, the USCCB's Committee on Pro-Life Activities announced a nationwide postcard campaign to blanket congressional offices and the White House with appeals to stop FOCA. Anti-FOCA groups on Facebook soon had more than 150,000 members and added thousands more each day. Priests started preaching against the legislation, and churches began circulating petitions to oppose its passage. In the midst of all this activity, the fact that there was no Freedom of Choice Act before the 111th Congress went largely unnoticed and unmentioned... James Salt, director of organizing for the progressive organization Catholics United, thinks the USCCB has been prodded into focusing on FOCA by misinformation from conservative groups. "These right-wing organizations are deliberatively misleading people in order to stoke the culture war," says Salt. "They're using this as a fundraising tool, as a way to gin up their relevancy. And unfortunately, some of these groups have the ear of certain bishops."... While the USCCB's literature about FOCA has been generally accurate, the chain e-mail has disseminated a number of false claims, including warnings that the proposal would force Catholic hospitals to shut down and lead to at least 100,000 more abortions each year. Some versions of the e-mail even claimed that FOCA could "result in a future amendment that would force women by law to have abortions in certain situations — and even regulate how many children women are allowed to have." In response, Catholic News Service — the official news agency affiliated with the USCCB — ran an article that began, "Internet rumors to the contrary, no Catholic hospital in the United States is in danger of closing because of the Freedom of Choice Act." Sister Carol Keehan, president and CEO of the Catholic Health Association, told the news agency that the legislation "has never contained anything that would force Catholic hospitals or Catholic personnel to do abortions or to participate in them." How like the frequent claims that "The Obama Adminstration wants to re-institute the Fairness Doctrine" (also not based on any real facts). How many of you Pro-Life readers have been taken in by these lies and have contacted your Senators and representatives to oppose a proposed law or law that doesn't even exist? Do you feel just a little bit foolish?

content: I read this a few days ago. Seriously, if you have to FABRICATE something in order to have a "cause," you need to find something new to twist your panties. They have to play make-believe, lie about it to everyone, pretend there's some sort of Red-China agenda underway to limit people's reproductive freedom, and then scream bloody murder... just so they can feel important. Wait, I mean... "self-important." They'd do a lot more in the long run to help their cause if they didn't lie to make things seem more dramatic. I wonder how many Catholics are going to feel completely disillusioned or deceived when they realize that the church lied to them to get them to donate more money and so on. I can respect both sides of this issue - because I've been on both sides at different times, and I still sympathize with both - but I can't stomach lying to promote a cause.

If you do some research, you will also see that Catholic run hospitals and some doctors have already had lawsuits filed for refusing to allow abotrtions in their facilities or by their hands. The way our so-called legislative representatives have acted in the past and continue to act is a bit more subversive than to place a controversial piece of legislation out in the open for scrutiny. Catholics as well as a number of other religious philosophies believe in the sanctity of life! Abortion is a violation of that precept. There is no grey area!

content: quote: During his tenure in the United States Senate, Barack Obama co-sponsored the 2007 Senate version of the Freedom of Choice Act (S. 1173). Responding to a question regarding how he would preserve reproductive rights in a speech given to the Planned Parenthood Action Fund on July 17, 2007, Obama declared, "The first thing I'd do, as president, is sign the Freedom of Choice Act. That's the first thing that I'd do." What Catholics must do is hope that this was just another false political promise made by the Obama!

content: The one who should feel foolish, if not downright stupid, is the OP. While the bill has not been formally introduced in this Congress, it was in the last Congress (as well as in 1989 and 1993) ... and was co-sponsored by POTUS 44. Since NARAL has been and is trumpeting this legislation and since it seems likely that it will be reintroduced in the current Congress, it seems perfectly reasonable to me to oppose that which NARAL is lobbying for extensively. If NARAL and their ilk back away from their support for the bill, perhaps the Catholic Church will not see the need for a vocal opposition. Silly and superficial thread ... fabricated and slanted issue ... even if (or perhaps because) it originated with Time. That the bill has not been introduced yet in this Congress does not make it mythical ... it is very real.

content: quote: Still, it's not on the table at the moment. It hasn't been presented to this congress. Your dismissal of the FOCA brings to mind Martin Niemoller. He was a German pastor who supported Adolf Hitler because they were both anti-communists. Then Hitler took another step and not only wanted total separation of Church and State but that the State was supreme and Niemoller protested. Niemoller organized other clergymen to protest the laws proposed by Nazis and their 'blame' of various groups for the economic and social woes of Germany. Others gave in to the Nazis' threats. Hitler arrested Niemoller and confined him in the Sachsenhausen and Dachau concentration camps. Niemoller was released in 1945 by the Allies. His poem is well-known, frequently quoted, and is a popular model for describing the dangers of political apathy, as it often begins with specific and targeted fear and hatred which soon escalates out of control. "When the Nazis came for the communists, I remained silent; I was not a communist. When they locked up the social democrats, I remained silent; I was not a social democrat. When they came for the trade unionists, I did not speak out; I was not a trade unionist. When they came for the Jews, I remained silent; I was not a Jew. When they came for me, there was no one left to speak out." Hitler claimed to be a Christian and was also a great orator making promises to each group of Germans on how he would make life better and 'fairer'! Our 'Great Depression' was mild compared to what was taking place in Germany and throughout Europe at the same time. He first eroded then destroyed German rights similar to those we call our "Bill of Rights" - Freedom of Speech; Freedom of Religion; Right to bear arms; unwarranted Search and Seizure; etc. Contrary to popular belief, slavery was a minor factor of the causes of our Civil War. Economically, both the Industrialized North and more rural South relied on 'cheap' labor. The North because of its manufacturing and urban centers could rely on the population to provide that work force. Wages were so low, households were barely able to survive but the 'American Dream' of advancement was there and as most were from the European 'serfdom' heritage; it was better than what they were used to. The Rural south also needed a nearby work force for the larger 'plantations' and cheap labor - Slavery. The second major factor was the difference between State rights and Federal control. Again do to diparity of the population in size and economic status, the Southern States were largly ignored in receiving benefit of a Federal Government or even much voice in its operation. Similar to today with the smaller States getting a few crumbs and having little influence over the Federal System or their own resources. Lincoln inherited the 'Civil War' from James Buchanan; Seven States had already seceded and Lincoln was not even on the ballot in the 'Slave States'. Hopfully our clearer heads will prevail today but only if we listen, watch and protest! ... and this means that we have to make our voices heard before our Government Officials propose or enact legislation or policy not after the fact.

content: If I wanted to compare Hitler to Obama, I would say it! I've never been one to be politically correct and if that offends, so be it - As to "increasing individual rights" which individual; the group that finds the 'right' immoral or unethical? As a 'God believing' thinking creature, my obligation is to stand firm on my moral foundation even if I have to stand alone! I associate on occassion with society but I live with 'myself" and I want to view that person I see in the mirror as one I can be proud of, not some wimp that follows the crowd or easy way. I am an American of Celtic ancestry, not by choice, but I did choose to follow the philosophy of a Jew! I have also relied on that Jew to lead me to salvation! quote: Besides, in terms of restricting rights, were you this vocal about defending your freedoms that were trampled by the Patriot Act? As a political or moral issue? ... or gun control; or ... My priorities are my God, my Family, and my Country - in that order. The patriot act did not 'erase' my rights or those of any other American citizen but it did limit those rights. It was a political choice of 'Safety' over 'freedom' due to a threat to both. Although, I have never read the complete Patriot act, from what I have gleaned, it was mor an inconvenience than a 'trampling' of mine and others rights or freedoms. quote: Hitler was the classic extreme of right-wing politics. Perhaps we should take note of this. Hitler right wing? Stalin left wing? I don't think you can pigeonhole anyone, although both were fanatical in their beliefs and practices. Glad to know that my History Lesson was information you already knew. But as with all 'lessons', the importance is what you do with that knowlege; in other words, How do you apply the lesson? As Maya Angelou said, "History, despite its wrenching pain, cannot be unlived, but if faced with courage, need not be lived again."

content: quote: Originally posted by 54D_Zippo: Although, I have never read the complete Patriot act, from what I have gleaned, it was mor an inconvenience than a 'trampling' of mine and others rights or freedoms. Then I would highly suggest that you DO read it, and try to internalize the extent of the risk to our REAL Constitutional Rights and Civil Liberties it actually posed, and the times when it actually DID impose on the Constitutional Rights of American citizens who were not in any way affiliated with terrorists. We had members of the press being arrested, harassed, and blocked, all under the carte blanche of the Patriot Act. These stories were conveniently ignored (read: hushed up) in the mainstream media. As for people's religious freedom - it is a wonderful thing that all people in the United States are supposed to have religious freedom. However, that right is also meant to ensure that the religious beliefs of one group are not imposed on another group. Example: You believe that it is evil to wear the color orange. You have the right to not wear orange. You can not stop someone else from wearing orange. You claim youy religion prohibits abortion. Having read the Bible more than once, I've not seen any passage that equates abortion with murder, but hey, believe whatever you want. You have the right to never participate in an abortion if you believe it's evil. However, imposing your religious beliefs on someone else restricts their freedoms, and the "fine line" between infanticide and abortion of a non-viable fetus isn't really such a fine line from a medical stance. But I can agree with one thing you said: You can't pigeonhole extremism. I think we can recognize real extremism when we see it, and can pretty much agree it's bad news.

If this passage indicates life before birth, then it also indicates LIFE BEFORE CONCEPTION. It says "Before I formed you in the womb," which would mean before conception. And in this passage, it refers to the SOUL, not the physical life. It refers to God's foreknowledge of the future, that God knows the future, and the planned creation of a special prophet, not that someone is alive before birth or before conception. Nice red herring, but I've studied that passage. It doesn't fly. Tell me where in the Bible is says that intentionally causing the termination of pregnancy is murder.

content: quote: Originally posted by transport1: Like the other's he's already signed into law, the ones that we still don't know about. Bout as transparent as aluminum. Oppsy Transport1, seems your behind the times once again Oppsy Transport1, seems your behind the times once again... quote: Air Force testing new transparent armor -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Story Tools Printable story E-mail story Subscribe now -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- by Laura Lundin Air Force Research Laboratory Public Affairs 10/17/2005 - WRIGHT-PATTERSON AIR FORCE BASE, Ohio (AFPN) -- Engineers here are testing a new kind of transparent armor -- stronger and lighter than traditional materials -- that could stop armor-piercing weapons from penetrating vehicle windows. The Air Force Research Laboratory's materials and manufacturing directorate is testing aluminum oxynitride -- ALONtm -- as a replacement for the traditional multi-layered glass transparencies now used in existing ground and air armored vehicles. The test is being done in conjunction with the Army Research Laboratory at Aberdeen Proving Grounds, Md., and University of Dayton Research Institute, Ohio. ALONtm is a ceramic compound with a high compressive strength and durability. When polished, it is the premier transparent armor for use in armored vehicles, said. 1st Lt. Joseph La Monica, transparent armor sub-direction lead "The substance itself is light years ahead of glass," he said, adding that it offers "higher performance and lighter weight." Traditional transparent armor is thick layers of bonded glass. The new armor combines the transparent ALONtm piece as a strike plate, a middle section of glass and a polymer backing. Each layer is visibly thinner than the traditional layers. ALONtm is virtually scratch resistant, offers substantial impact resistance, and provides better durability and protection against armor piercing threats, at roughly half the weight and half the thickness of traditional glass transparent armor, said the lieutenant. but keep trying.

content: "http://www.time.com/time/printout/0,8816,1880451,00.html" quote: The U.S. Catholic Church's crusade against the Freedom of Choice Act (FOCA) has all the hallmarks of a well-oiled lobbying campaign. A national postcard campaign is flooding the White House and congressional offices with messages opposing FOCA, and Catholic bishops have made defeating the abortion rights legislation a top priority. In the most recent effort to stop the bill, Cardinal Justin Rigali of Philadelphia sent a letter to every member of Congress imploring them to "please oppose FOCA." There is only one hitch. Congress isn't about to pass the Freedom of Choice Act — because no such bill has been introduced in the current Congress. At a time when the United States is gripped by economic uncertainty and faces serious challenges in hot spots around the globe, some American Catholics are finding it both curious and troubling that their church has launched a major campaign against a piece of legislation that doesn't exist and wouldn't have much chance of becoming law even if it did. To many critics, it feels like the legislative equivalent of the dog that didn't bark. The campaign against FOCA, which would essentially codify the Roe v. Wade decision by saying the government can't place limits on abortions performed before viability, began shortly after Barack Obama's election in November, at the annual general meeting of the U.S. Conference of Catholic Bishops (USCCB). In a unanimous decision, the bishops voted to "mobilize the resources of the USCCB, dioceses and the entire Catholic community" to oppose the act. A chain e-mail of unknown origin soon began making its way into Catholic inboxes, warning of an imminent threat to the anti-abortion cause. "For those of you who do not know," it read, "the Freedom of Choice Act (FOCA) is set to be signed if Congress passes it on January 21-22 of 2009. The FOCA is the next sick chapter in the book of abortion." The e-mail urged Catholics to say a novena — a devotion of dedicated prayer for nine successive days — beginning on Jan. 11 and ending the day prior to Inauguration Day. When Jan. 22 came and went without a Freedom of Choice Act becoming law, the USCCB's Committee on Pro-Life Activities announced a nationwide postcard campaign to blanket congressional offices and the White House with appeals to stop FOCA. Anti-FOCA groups on Facebook soon had more than 150,000 members and added thousands more each day. Priests started preaching against the legislation, and churches began circulating petitions to oppose its passage. In the midst of all this activity, the fact that there was no Freedom of Choice Act before the 111th Congress went largely unnoticed and unmentioned... James Salt, director of organizing for the progressive organization Catholics United, thinks the USCCB has been prodded into focusing on FOCA by misinformation from conservative groups. "These right-wing organizations are deliberatively misleading people in order to stoke the culture war," says Salt. "They're using this as a fundraising tool, as a way to gin up their relevancy. And unfortunately, some of these groups have the ear of certain bishops."... While the USCCB's literature about FOCA has been generally accurate, the chain e-mail has disseminated a number of false claims, including warnings that the proposal would force Catholic hospitals to shut down and lead to at least 100,000 more abortions each year. Some versions of the e-mail even claimed that FOCA could "result in a future amendment that would force women by law to have abortions in certain situations — and even regulate how many children women are allowed to have." In response, Catholic News Service — the official news agency affiliated with the USCCB — ran an article that began, "Internet rumors to the contrary, no Catholic hospital in the United States is in danger of closing because of the Freedom of Choice Act." Sister Carol Keehan, president and CEO of the Catholic Health Association, told the news agency that the legislation "has never contained anything that would force Catholic hospitals or Catholic personnel to do abortions or to participate in them." How like the frequent claims that "The Obama Adminstration wants to re-institute the Fairness Doctrine" (also not based on any real facts). How many of you Pro-Life readers have been taken in by these lies and have contacted your Senators and representatives to oppose a proposed law or law that doesn't even exist? Do you feel just a little bit foolish?

content: The one who should feel foolish, if not downright stupid, is the OP. While the bill has not been formally introduced in this Congress, it was in the last Congress (as well as in 1989 and 1993) ... and was co-sponsored by POTUS 44. Since NARAL has been and is trumpeting this legislation and since it seems likely that it will be reintroduced in the current Congress, it seems perfectly reasonable to me to oppose that which NARAL is lobbying for extensively. If NARAL and their ilk back away from their support for the bill, perhaps the Catholic Church will not see the need for a vocal opposition. Silly and superficial thread ... fabricated and slanted issue ... even if (or perhaps because) it originated with Time. That the bill has not been introduced yet in this Congress does not make it mythical ... it is very real.

content: quote: Still, it's not on the table at the moment. It hasn't been presented to this congress. Your dismissal of the FOCA brings to mind Martin Niemoller. He was a German pastor who supported Adolf Hitler because they were both anti-communists. Then Hitler took another step and not only wanted total separation of Church and State but that the State was supreme and Niemoller protested. Niemoller organized other clergymen to protest the laws proposed by Nazis and their 'blame' of various groups for the economic and social woes of Germany. Others gave in to the Nazis' threats. Hitler arrested Niemoller and confined him in the Sachsenhausen and Dachau concentration camps. Niemoller was released in 1945 by the Allies. His poem is well-known, frequently quoted, and is a popular model for describing the dangers of political apathy, as it often begins with specific and targeted fear and hatred which soon escalates out of control. "When the Nazis came for the communists, I remained silent; I was not a communist. When they locked up the social democrats, I remained silent; I was not a social democrat. When they came for the trade unionists, I did not speak out; I was not a trade unionist. When they came for the Jews, I remained silent; I was not a Jew. When they came for me, there was no one left to speak out." Hitler claimed to be a Christian and was also a great orator making promises to each group of Germans on how he would make life better and 'fairer'! Our 'Great Depression' was mild compared to what was taking place in Germany and throughout Europe at the same time. He first eroded then destroyed German rights similar to those we call our "Bill of Rights" - Freedom of Speech; Freedom of Religion; Right to bear arms; unwarranted Search and Seizure; etc. Contrary to popular belief, slavery was a minor factor of the causes of our Civil War. Economically, both the Industrialized North and more rural South relied on 'cheap' labor. The North because of its manufacturing and urban centers could rely on the population to provide that work force. Wages were so low, households were barely able to survive but the 'American Dream' of advancement was there and as most were from the European 'serfdom' heritage; it was better than what they were used to. The Rural south also needed a nearby work force for the larger 'plantations' and cheap labor - Slavery. The second major factor was the difference between State rights and Federal control. Again do to diparity of the population in size and economic status, the Southern States were largly ignored in receiving benefit of a Federal Government or even much voice in its operation. Similar to today with the smaller States getting a few crumbs and having little influence over the Federal System or their own resources. Lincoln inherited the 'Civil War' from James Buchanan; Seven States had already seceded and Lincoln was not even on the ballot in the 'Slave States'. Hopfully our clearer heads will prevail today but only if we listen, watch and protest! ... and this means that we have to make our voices heard before our Government Officials propose or enact legislation or policy not after the fact.
quote: Still, it's not on the table at the moment. It hasn't been presented to this congress.
reply: Your dismissal of the FOCA brings to mind Martin Niemoller. He was a German pastor who supported Adolf Hitler because they were both anti-communists. Then Hitler took another step and not only wanted total separation of Church and State but that the State was supreme and Niemoller protested. Niemoller organized other clergymen to protest the laws proposed by Nazis and their 'blame' of various groups for the economic and social woes of Germany. Others gave in to the Nazis' threats. Hitler arrested Niemoller and confined him in the Sachsenhausen and Dachau concentration camps. Niemoller was released in 1945 by the Allies. His poem is well-known, frequently quoted, and is a popular model for describing the dangers of political apathy, as it often begins with specific and targeted fear and hatred which soon escalates out of control. "When the Nazis came for the communists, I remained silent; I was not a communist. When they locked up the social democrats, I remained silent; I was not a social democrat. When they came for the trade unionists, I did not speak out; I was not a trade unionist. When they came for the Jews, I remained silent; I was not a Jew. When they came for me, there was no one left to speak out." Hitler claimed to be a Christian and was also a great orator making promises to each group of Germans on how he would make life better and 'fairer'! Our 'Great Depression' was mild compared to what was taking place in Germany and throughout Europe at the same time. He first eroded then destroyed German rights similar to those we call our "Bill of Rights" - Freedom of Speech; Freedom of Religion; Right to bear arms; unwarranted Search and Seizure; etc. Contrary to popular belief, slavery was a minor factor of the causes of our Civil War. Economically, both the Industrialized North and more rural South relied on 'cheap' labor. The North because of its manufacturing and urban centers could rely on the population to provide that work force. Wages were so low, households were barely able to survive but the 'American Dream' of advancement was there and as most were from the European 'serfdom' heritage; it was better than what they were used to. The Rural south also needed a nearby work force for the larger 'plantations' and cheap labor - Slavery. The second major factor was the difference between State rights and Federal control. Again do to diparity of the population in size and economic status, the Southern States were largly ignored in receiving benefit of a Federal Government or even much voice in its operation. Similar to today with the smaller States getting a few crumbs and having little influence over the Federal System or their own resources. Lincoln inherited the 'Civil War' from James Buchanan; Seven States had already seceded and Lincoln was not even on the ballot in the 'Slave States'. Hopfully our clearer heads will prevail today but only if we listen, watch and protest! ... and this means that we have to make our voices heard before our Government Officials propose or enact legislation or policy not after the fact.
title: The Catholic Crusade Against a Mythical Abortion Bill

content: If I wanted to compare Hitler to Obama, I would say it! I've never been one to be politically correct and if that offends, so be it - As to "increasing individual rights" which individual; the group that finds the 'right' immoral or unethical? As a 'God believing' thinking creature, my obligation is to stand firm on my moral foundation even if I have to stand alone! I associate on occassion with society but I live with 'myself" and I want to view that person I see in the mirror as one I can be proud of, not some wimp that follows the crowd or easy way. I am an American of Celtic ancestry, not by choice, but I did choose to follow the philosophy of a Jew! I have also relied on that Jew to lead me to salvation! quote: Besides, in terms of restricting rights, were you this vocal about defending your freedoms that were trampled by the Patriot Act? As a political or moral issue? ... or gun control; or ... My priorities are my God, my Family, and my Country - in that order. The patriot act did not 'erase' my rights or those of any other American citizen but it did limit those rights. It was a political choice of 'Safety' over 'freedom' due to a threat to both. Although, I have never read the complete Patriot act, from what I have gleaned, it was mor an inconvenience than a 'trampling' of mine and others rights or freedoms. quote: Hitler was the classic extreme of right-wing politics. Perhaps we should take note of this. Hitler right wing? Stalin left wing? I don't think you can pigeonhole anyone, although both were fanatical in their beliefs and practices. Glad to know that my History Lesson was information you already knew. But as with all 'lessons', the importance is what you do with that knowlege; in other words, How do you apply the lesson? As Maya Angelou said, "History, despite its wrenching pain, cannot be unlived, but if faced with courage, need not be lived again."

Then I would highly suggest that you DO read it, and try to internalize the extent of the risk to our REAL Constitutional Rights and Civil Liberties it actually posed, and the times when it actually DID impose on the Constitutional Rights of American citizens who were not in any way affiliated with terrorists. We had members of the press being arrested, harassed, and blocked, all under the carte blanche of the Patriot Act. These stories were conveniently ignored (read: hushed up) in the mainstream media. As for people's religious freedom - it is a wonderful thing that all people in the United States are supposed to have religious freedom. However, that right is also meant to ensure that the religious beliefs of one group are not imposed on another group. Example: You believe that it is evil to wear the color orange. You have the right to not wear orange. You can not stop someone else from wearing orange. You claim youy religion prohibits abortion. Having read the Bible more than once, I've not seen any passage that equates abortion with murder, but hey, believe whatever you want. You have the right to never participate in an abortion if you believe it's evil. However, imposing your religious beliefs on someone else restricts their freedoms, and the "fine line" between infanticide and abortion of a non-viable fetus isn't really such a fine line from a medical stance. But I can agree with one thing you said: You can't pigeonhole extremism. I think we can recognize real extremism when we see it, and can pretty much agree it's bad news.

content: quote: Originally posted by transport1: Like the other's he's already signed into law, the ones that we still don't know about. Bout as transparent as aluminum. Oppsy Transport1, seems your behind the times once again Oppsy Transport1, seems your behind the times once again... quote: Air Force testing new transparent armor -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Story Tools Printable story E-mail story Subscribe now -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- by Laura Lundin Air Force Research Laboratory Public Affairs 10/17/2005 - WRIGHT-PATTERSON AIR FORCE BASE, Ohio (AFPN) -- Engineers here are testing a new kind of transparent armor -- stronger and lighter than traditional materials -- that could stop armor-piercing weapons from penetrating vehicle windows. The Air Force Research Laboratory's materials and manufacturing directorate is testing aluminum oxynitride -- ALONtm -- as a replacement for the traditional multi-layered glass transparencies now used in existing ground and air armored vehicles. The test is being done in conjunction with the Army Research Laboratory at Aberdeen Proving Grounds, Md., and University of Dayton Research Institute, Ohio. ALONtm is a ceramic compound with a high compressive strength and durability. When polished, it is the premier transparent armor for use in armored vehicles, said. 1st Lt. Joseph La Monica, transparent armor sub-direction lead "The substance itself is light years ahead of glass," he said, adding that it offers "higher performance and lighter weight." Traditional transparent armor is thick layers of bonded glass. The new armor combines the transparent ALONtm piece as a strike plate, a middle section of glass and a polymer backing. Each layer is visibly thinner than the traditional layers. ALONtm is virtually scratch resistant, offers substantial impact resistance, and provides better durability and protection against armor piercing threats, at roughly half the weight and half the thickness of traditional glass transparent armor, said the lieutenant. but keep trying.
